Adalaj stepwell is also called Rudabhai Step well, named after the queen, in whose honor it was built. Felt so happy we could visit this place and admire the beauty of it.

Stepwells are basically wells for washing, drinking and bathing purely for the ladies and it is very common in Gujarat and rajasthan area. The earliest step wells date back to 2nd century AD.

Over time, these step wells became an architectural marvel and wonderful place to show case their talent, their intricate carvings, their stunning symmetry. It is a wonderful place not only  for history lovers but for photographers too.

The Rudabhai step well is a five storied step well, built in 1498 by the then king Rana veer singh but completed in record time by Mohammed Begda the muslim ruler who killed Rana veer singh in battle.

Legend says, the queen Rudabhai tricked mohammed begda to finish the step well in record time on the condition that she will marry him, but when the step well was completed, she went back on her promise and killed her self in this step well.

You can also see some tombs on the step well and the legend goes that the mohammed begda killed the people who constructed such a fantastic step well in record time.

Definitely a must visit place if you are visiting Gujarat and in particular Ahmedabad. The place is more beautiful when you see it with your own eyes than in the photographs that you see on the net.

I like places that have historical significance, it shows where we are heading as a society. Everything around here is well maintained from the lush green parks to the maintenance of the stepwell. The smell of bats is one issue but again that's what makes this place authentic.
Very nice place, marvellous architecture and art is presented here. Spent some great time. Cabs and autos easily available to this place. Must visit

The history of this stepwell comes alive through a Sanskrit inscription in Devanagari script, found on a marble slab placed in a niche on the first floor, near the eastern entrance. It was built by Ruda, the wife of Virsinh, and is also known as Rudabai Stepwell.

The area around the stepwell is beautifully green and peaceful. On weekends, it does get a little crowded, but still worth visiting. The color of the water is surprisingly beautiful, and the intricate carvings and architectural design will truly leave you amazed.

It‚Äôs a reminder of how advanced and artistically rich India was centuries ago. Even today, the structure stands strong and captivating ‚Äî a must-visit for anyone who appreciates heritage and history.

There is shilalekh in the well which tells story of the well. This well built in the 15th century. Very good place to visit with family and friends at any season.

Visit this place only if this is in your bucket list and this place is coming your way, a decent monument, though a great architectural marvel, you will complete this within half and hour, four storey monument, it requires a little bit of renovation, and the water stinks a lot.

Built in the year 1572-73 by an Abyssinian (person from Ethiopia) called Sidi Saiyyed, who served under the then sultan. This mosque is well known for the wonderful intricate carvings in stone and their unique semi circular tracery windows, depicting the tree of life.

Paper cutouts were made of the carved screens from which two wooden replicas were made and these are now in museum in London and New york.

The driver was telling us that this mosque is still in use as the emblem of the Ahmedabad municipality.

The grave of sidi saiyyed is inside this mosque.

placeMetadata.name: The Calico Museum of Textiles

sources.snippet: India‚Äôs finest textile museum was established by Gira Sarabhai, under the aegis of the Sarabhai Foundation, in 1949. The museum showcases the rich and diverse textile culture of the Manchester of the East, and is ‚Äúamong the best repositories of Indian textiles and garments,‚Äù says Anupa Mehta, art consultant and gallerist.The displays offer a closer look at painted, printed, woven, resist-dyed, and textiles from different time periods and parts of the country. The standout items include a Mughal tent, a 27-feet long pattachitra, a large kalamkari, a ghaghra with 400 panels, and intricately patterned double ikat and tied-dye textiles.Timings: Museum Tour from 10:30am-12:30pm; 2:30pm-4:30pm (Tues-Sun); Garden Tour from 3:30pm-5pm (Thu)
sources.shortName: 22 places to visit in Ahmedabad that are not tourist traps

sources.snippet: Calico Textile Museum was established in 1949 by the Sarabhai foundation and is located in the heart of Ahmadabad‚Äôs textile industry. The museum was originally located at the calico mills but as the collection grew it was moved to a carved haveli which was the former residence of the Sarabhai family. The museum displays textiles used by the mughals and several types of cloths manufactured during the 19th century.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places To Visit In Ahmedabad

sources.snippet: At Calico Museum one has the opportunity to see a collection of rare textiles such as royal tents, costumes and carpets. The museum was established in 1949 and displays 17th and 18th century‚Äôs collection of religious paintings on cloth, embroideries, brocades and silk weaves and Kashmiri Shawls. The Calico Museum is situated in the Shahi Bagh Garden and is spread over 12 rooms and across two stories.

sources.snippet: Calico Museum of Textiles ‚Äì Among the Best Tourist Places in Ahmedabad. I for one enjoyed the experience thoroughly. Unlike what others have said I found the process of registering for the tour quite straight forward. We turned up at the museum and were politely turned away and told we had to register for the tour. Registered for the next day and received an email immediately. The guide was knowledgeable and also was able to keep the flock together and complete the tour in the allotted time. The tea and boiled groundnuts at the end of the tour was a welcome gesture... specially as it was a free tour! Kudos to the museum for a well kept and tastefully done display.

The hidden gem in Ahmedabad that‚Äôs a must-visit for anyone interested in Indian textiles: a remarkable museum showcasing an exquisite collection. Housed in the former residence of Shri Ambalal Sarabhai, this museum requires advance booking through their website, as they limit entry to about 20 visitors at a time. Words can‚Äôt fully capture the beauty and depth of the collection‚Äîyou simply have to experience it firsthand. Our tour guide, a delightful lady with a great sense of humor, made the visit even more enjoyable, and I‚Äôm deeply grateful for her insights. Note that cameras, phones, and large bags are not permitted inside.

Booking is the biggest pain that spoils the overall experience.
Booking:
2 months in advance of the exact date of visit, we have registered each one of the family members on their website.
‚ÄúReceived your request‚Äù was the only message that we have received until 2 weeks prior to the visit.
2 Weeks prior to the visit proactively pursued with them several times, and luckily chanced to connect telephonically with a gentleman around 1030am.
Soon at the end of the call, we have received ‚Äúyour request has been accepted ‚Äú in our email box.
Visit:
Better to be there 10 minutes prior to the exact time.

Security, now a days, has the facility to place your stuff like mobiles etc in shelves, with lock n key.

Welcome
Visitors are welcomed by ever passionate highly knowledgeable lady staff member who takes you thru the aisles and environment for wonderful exposition on artefacts. Yet times she may go overboard, well small price to pay for exceptional experience on variety of textiles.

Hospitality:
Now a days (when compared to 20yrs ago), at the end of the guided tour, you are hosted with snacks and tea, and warm send off.

It was a good experience not an excellent one though as I had expected. Let me begin with good things first. The textile heritage of the country has been preserved here unlike elsewhere in India. Despite being very old, the space was very neat and clean, odour free, lush green and peaceful. Even though it was a 2 hour guided tour, it was absolutely free of cost and at the end of the tour we were also offered a very tasty tea with boiled groundnuts which was a refreshing experience after 2 hour long tour. The lady guide was extremely passionate about the subject. The textile collection is diverse and representative of various states.

Now, coming to improvements, the owners limit the number of visitors which seems to be in contradiction with the vision of owners to let the world at large know of the rich indian heritage. In the age of technology, manual guide seems like too monotonous and repetitive and less interesting. There are 3 different tours and you can't do all in one day. A visitor to a state doesn't like to come to the same place every day. It's a private museum and you need to book in advance and share lot of personal data and information which looks risky from the point of view of privacy in today's day and time. Not being able to take camera along is another dampener as you don't have any memories to take along for long time. Thol, the artificial lake in Gujarat, India, offers a mixed experience. The trails, unfortunately, are not well maintained, urging visitors to opt for two-wheelers. For those seeking tranquility, an early morning visit at 6 AM or 6:30 AM is recommended to witness a breathtaking sunrise and the enchanting presence of majestic birds. A canteen on-site provides basic refreshments. Beware of mischievous monkeys roaming the area. Weekends, however, come with a downside as parking fees surge to ‚Çπ500, compared to the regular ‚Çπ400 on weekdays. Despite the maintenance issues and fluctuating prices, Thol's natural beauty and avian wonders make it worth considering for nature enthusiasts and early risers.

If you enjoy nature, peace, and watching birds in their natural surroundings, Thol Bird Sanctuary is a beautiful escape. Whether you're a photographer, bird enthusiast, or just someone looking for a serene day out, this place is definitely worth a visit.

placeMetadata.name: Sabarmati Ashram

sources.snippet: The Gandhi Ashram, located on the banks of the Sabarmati, is a must-visit when on the Gandhi trail. Home to Gandhi from 1917 to 1930, Sabarmati Ashram was one of the key places from where the struggle for Indian Independence started. He launched the Dandi March to protest against the British Salt Law from here on March 12, 1930.
sources.shortName: 22 places to visit in Ahmedabad that are not tourist traps

sources.snippet: Located at the banks of the Sabarmati River, the Ashram was established by the very hands of Mahatama Gandhi who resided here for 12 years. Sabarmati Ashram was known to be the focal point of the non-violent movement against freedom and also served as the base for the famous Salt Satyagrah. According to the ancient Hindu texts, the ashram is said to be located on the ancient site where sage Dadhich sacrificed his ribcage to make weapons for the Gods.
sources.shortName: Top 10 Places To Visit In Ahmedabad

sources.snippet: 3 km from city center 4 out of 64 Places To Visit in Ahmedabad. Once the residence of Mahatma Gandhi and his wife Kasturba, this undoubtedly is the biggest tourist attraction situated in the suburb of Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Located on the tranquil and serene stretch of Sabarmati River it was also referred to as the 'Satyagraha Ashram' as Gandhi began the famous 'Dandi March' from here.

It served as the residence for Mahatma Gandhi and his wife Kasturba Gandhi. The ashram is renowned for being the starting point of Gandhi's famous Dandi March.

reviews.reviewText:
A visit to Sabarmati Ashram is not just a journey through space, but through time and ideals. Nestled quietly along the banks of the serene Sabarmati River in Ahmedabad, this ashram‚Äîonce home to Mahatma Gandhi from 1917 to 1930‚Äîis a living testimony to India's freedom struggle.

Though Ahmedabad has grown into a bustling city, the path to the ashram still holds a certain calm. Passing through well-developed riverfront roads adorned with parks and gardens, we reached the 'Magan Gandhi Gate'‚Äîa quieter entrance. Despite being a weekend, the ashram remained calm and uncrowded, amplifying its aura of peace and simplicity.

Inside, the shady trees, humble buildings, and displays of Gandhi‚Äôs life and tools, especially inside Magan Nivas and Hriday Kunj, evoke deep reflection. Each corner, from prayer grounds to Gandhi‚Äôs study and sleeping quarters, feels sacred and grounded in history. Handwritten notes, rare photographs, and even traditional spinning wheels offer a quiet glimpse into the soul of the Mahatma.

The peaceful ambiance, chirping birds, and even the sight of graceful peacocks wandering in the lawns add to the spiritual feel of the place. It was deeply moving to walk through the places where Bapu meditated, wrote letters, spun khadi, and led a movement that changed the destiny of a nation.

Spending around four hours immersed in Gandhi‚Äôs world was an enriching experience. For anyone visiting Ahmedabad, Sabarmati Ashram is a must-visit‚Äînot just to admire history but to reflect on simplicity, truth, and inner strength.

Wonderful place, preserved in its original form. Greenery in the campus comes as a relief, from concrete jungle and buildings surrounding ashram. Car park and entry is free and no fees or tickets are imposed. Library, photo gallery, life size statues make museum remarkable. Visiting Ashram is a gentle reminder of how much as a nation we failed Bapu, especially with cleanliness related issues in the country.

We loved learning more about the Mahatma. The museum has a lot of signage, but very informative if you take a few minutes to read each sign. The Gandhi quotes never cease to inspire. There is a nice garden there and a short walk to the riverfront. We were met by adorable and inquisitive schoolchildren, eager to practice their English.

Visited Sabarmati Ashram as a law student along with my classmates and faculty members ‚Äî it was a truly enriching experience. The ashram holds deep historical significance, being the residence of Mahatma Gandhi and a center of India‚Äôs non-violent freedom movement. Walking through the peaceful surroundings, viewing preserved artifacts, letters, and photographs gave us a powerful insight into Gandhiji‚Äôs life and philosophy.

The environment is calm, well-maintained, and ideal for reflecting on the values of truth, justice, and non-violence. It was especially meaningful for us as law students to connect with the ideals that shaped India's legal and constitutional history.

A must-visit for anyone interested in Indian history, law, and values of social justice.

A serene and historically rich spot where you can experience the simplicity of Gandhiji‚Äôs way of life. The site is well-preserved, showcasing photographs, his contributions, and his modest living quarters. An essential stop for anyone interested in India‚Äôs independence movement, offering a tranquil atmosphere by the riverside.

Sabarmati Ashram is famous as the place where Mahatma Gandhi resided and launched the Dandi March, a pivotal event in India's independence movement. It served as his headquarters and a base for his activities related to the Indian freedom struggle.
Charles Correa designed the Sabarmati Ashram Museum in Ahmedabad, India to follow the principles of Mahatma Gandhi. The museum buildings are arranged in a casual meandering pattern around a central courtyard, with five rooms used to display important artifacts.

It's a glance of Mr. Gandhi life style and Her wife contribution towards India's struggle for freedom.
Sabarmati Ashram is a serene and historically significant place located on the banks of the Sabarmati River in Ahmedabad. It served as the residence of Mahatma Gandhi during India's freedom struggle and continues to inspire with its peaceful ambiance and rich legacy. The ashram beautifully preserves Gandhi's living quarters, letters, photographs, and personal belongings, offering deep insights into his simple lifestyle and powerful ideas. The museum is well-maintained and educational. A visit here fills the heart with respect and reflection. Truly a must-visit for anyone interested in Indian history and Gandhian values.

Its was peaceful on a Sunday.

reviews.reviewText: Nicely maintained museum. A must visit for vintage car enthusiasts. The cars were nicely maintained. There are also a few carriage and  bikes. The staff is also good. Entry fees are Rs. 100 for above 11 years of age and Rs. 50 for 11 and below. Rs. 100 are charges for photography using 1 camera/mobile. Videography costs more. The atmosphere around is very calm with peacocks and peahen playing around.

If you are in Ahmedabad this is a must visit place. There are around 122 cars and some horse carts that shows the evolution of transportation and also the style of cars. I was fascinated by how each one of them are maintained in spic and span conditions.
It easily takes 90 minutes to go through every car and observe the detailing. If you are an automobile design enthusiast you will cherish all the moments spent here. The venue is in private property which houses residence of the owner. The residence landscape is nicely maintained which adds to the charm. There is also a restaurant inside which I didn‚Äôt try.
I have deducted one star for the rude behaviour of the staff.  They seem to be guiding as if we are going to ruin the displays. I understand that many would be doing that but they get to understand customer experience especially when they are charging Rs 100 entry ticket. And additional Rs. 100 for every photography device.

Auto World Car Museum is a hidden gem for automobile lovers! The collection is truly impressive ‚Äì from vintage classics to luxury models, each car is beautifully maintained and displayed. The staff is friendly and knowledgeable, sharing interesting stories behind the cars. The layout is well-organized, making it easy to walk through and enjoy at your own pace. It's a must-visit if you're into cars or history. I was pleasantly surprised by the variety and rare models showcased. Highly recommended for families, tourists, and car enthusiasts!

There is entry prize around 100 rupees for clicking photographs. And there is a caf√© inside

Auto World Vintage Car Museum in Ahmedabad is a paradise for vintage car lovers. With over 100 rare and classic cars including Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Cadillac, and Mercedes, it offers a royal glimpse into automotive history. The cars are well-maintained, and you can even enjoy a short ride in a vintage car. The museum is clean, peaceful, and also has a small cafeteria and play area for kids. It‚Äôs a great place for families, tourists, and photography lovers. Perfect for a weekend visit if you love classic automobiles and want to experience the charm of a bygone era.

I had a wonderful experience visiting the Auto World Vintage Car Museum. The collection of vintage and classic cars is truly impressive‚Äîeach vehicle is beautifully maintained and reflects the rich automotive history. It‚Äôs a paradise for car lovers!

The museum is well-organized, and the staff is informative and polite. I also enjoyed the peaceful surroundings and the opportunity to see rare models up close. A great place to spend a couple of hours if you‚Äôre in the area. Highly recommended for automobile enthusiasts!

I visited this museum last month with my college alumni, and it was a memorable experience! The museum has an incredible collection of cars dating back to the late 1800s and early 1900s. From bullock-cart type cars to classic beauties from prestigious global brands, every vehicle is displayed with proper details like the year, maker, and country.

They also have iconic Indian cars such as the original Tata Nano and Maruti 800, along with a few vintage motorcycles. As an automobile enthusiast, I absolutely loved walking through the history and evolution of four-wheelers. It was fascinating to see how massive and beautifully designed old cars were compared to today‚Äôs compact models. The craftsmanship and design truly reflect the art and engineering of their time.

Tickets are required both for entry and for using your mobile camera. Initially, I felt the pricing was slightly on the higher side, but after seeing the rare collection and the way they‚Äôve maintained these vehicles, it felt worth it. Do note that only one phone is allowed per photo ticket, security guards are present at every corner, and video recording is not allowed.

üëâ Best time to visit is around lunchtime, as there is a Vintage Theam Restaurant inside the premises where you can enjoy a nice meal. That way you can easily spend an entire afternoon exploring cars and relaxing over food.

Overall, it was a crazy and satisfying experience. A must-visit for families, friends, and especially petrolheads who will appreciate every detail. Highly recommended!

The Auto World Vintage Car Museum in Ahmedabad is a must-visit for car enthusiasts and history lovers alike. Located on the peaceful Dastan Estate, about 20 km from the city center, it houses an impressive collection of over 100 vintage cars, including rare Rolls-Royce, Bentley, Jaguar, Maybach, and more‚Äîmany once owned by Indian royalty. The vehicles are beautifully preserved, and most are in running condition, with optional vintage car rides available inside the premises. The museum also features a Gujarati thali restaurant, kids‚Äô play area, and lush surroundings, making it a great family outing spot. Visitors appreciate the grandeur and variety of the cars, though some mention that the additional charges for photography and rides can be a bit high. Despite being on the outskirts, the experience is widely rated as unique and worth the trip for a glimpse into classic automotive elegance.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Jhulta Minar, also known as the Shaking Minarets, is a fascinating architectural wonder located in Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Situated within the Sidi Bashir Mosque complex, these minarets are renowned for their unique shaking phenomenon. When one minaret is shaken, the other starts shaking on its own despite being connected by intricate arches and corridors. This perplexing optical illusion has puzzled visitors for centuries and remains an unsolved mystery to this day.

Law Garden in Ahmedabad is a vibrant marketplace that offers a wide range of shopping, dining, and cultural experiences. Here's what you can expect:

*Pros:*

- *Shopping Paradise*: Law Garden is known for its diverse shopping options, including traditional Gujarati attire, handicrafts, and modern accessories. You can find everything from ethnic cholis to jootis and embroidered bags.
- *Street Food Delights*: The market offers a variety of delicious street food options, including Gujarati cuisine and ice cream parlors.
- *Cultural Immersion*: Law Garden provides a glimpse into Gujarat's rich cultural heritage, with live music performances, cultural programs, and a vibrant atmosphere.
- *Affordable Prices*: You can find affordable and reasonably priced items, but be prepared to haggle.

*Cons:*

- *Crowded and Less Decorative Shops*: Some visitors have reported that the shops are less decorative, and the owners can be stubborn.
- *Beware of Scams*: As with any popular market, be cautious of scams and ensure you're buying from reputable vendors ¬π ¬≤.

*Tips for Visiting Law Garden:*

- *Carry Cash*: Many vendors don't accept card payments, so it's best to carry cash.
- *Visit in the Evening*: The market comes alive in the evenings, making it the perfect time to experience the vibrant atmosphere.
- *Haggling is Common*: Don't be afraid to bargain for the best deals ¬≥ ‚Å¥

Ahmadabad, the former capital of Gujarat, is famously known for being the dry state of India and is also a famous tourist spot. Its aesthetic views, exotic eatables and their rich heritage, makes it one of the most visited locations. The old Ahmadabad is declared as India‚Äôs first UNESCO World Heritage City.

One of the most beautiful places to visit in Ahmedabad is Vastrapur Lake. This quiet place acts as a getaway from the hubbubs of the chaotic city, while being located in the heart of the city. This lake is surrounded with thick lustrous green garden and the river side are embellished with various stones. At various occasions the water from Narmada River is allowed to flow into this river.

The round pathway along the river attracts many health-conscious people for morning jog or workout. Vastrapur Lake also acts as the cultural hub of the city, as many cultural events are organized on the lustrous green lawn along the river bank.

This place is an ideal weekend visit for a family picnic or maybe a small outing in the evening. This place is also ideal for children as it offers a children park especially designed for the amusement of the small humans. The park is open to its visitors every day from 8 am to 10 pm, no entry fees are charged to its visitors.

placeMetadata.name: Hutheesing Jain Temple

sources.snippet: Built by a Jain Merchant named Hutheesing Kesarsing in 1850, Hutheesing Jain Temple is situated outside the Delhi Gate. The temple is made of marble and is dedicated to Dharmanath, who was the 15th Jain Tirthankara. The marbles are intricately carved and the paved courtyard of the temple has 52 cubicles that house shrines dedicated to different Tirthankaras.

The Hutheesing Jain Temple in Ahmedabad is truly a masterpiece of architecture, devotion, and history. Built in the mid-19th century, this marble temple stands as a symbol of faith and dedication. The moment you enter, you are greeted with intricate carvings, beautifully sculpted pillars, and a serene atmosphere that instantly brings peace to the mind.

The craftsmanship here is extraordinary ‚Äî every detail on the walls, domes, and ceilings speaks of the unmatched skill of artisans of that era. The temple complex is not only a place of worship but also a living gallery of India‚Äôs rich architectural heritage.

One of the highlights is the Manastambha (tower of glory), standing tall and gracefully carved, symbolizing victory of the soul over material desires. The pathways, marble flooring, and arches reflect both beauty and tranquility, making it a perfect spot for inner reflection.

The temple premises are well maintained, calm, and filled with positive energy. Visitors are expected to maintain silence and respect the sanctity of the place, which adds to the divine experience.

Overall, Hutheesing Jain Temple is not just a religious site but a cultural jewel of Ahmedabad. Whether you are spiritually inclined, an admirer of heritage, or simply someone who loves peaceful places, this temple is a must-visit.
Really beautiful temple. It's one of the various countless examples of stunning architecture that continue to keep our history alive.

Hutheesing Jain Temple, Ahmedabad ‚Äì A Sanctuary of Serenity and Spiritual Grace

Nestled in the heart of Ahmedabad, the Hutheesing Jain Temple stands as a timeless tribute to devotion, architecture, and spiritual tranquility. As soon as you step through its intricately carved entrance, a deep sense of peace envelops you, offering immediate relief from the noise and rush of the outside world.

Built in 1848 by a Jain merchant, Sheth Hutheesing, this temple is dedicated to the 15th Jain Tirthankara, Shri Dharmanatha. Crafted primarily from white marble, the temple is a marvel of design, with its delicate carvings, domed ceilings, and latticed windows casting intricate shadows that shift beautifully with the daylight. The sacred chants that gently echo through the sanctum enhance the divine ambience, encouraging reflection and inner calm.

The temple‚Äôs courtyard, adorned with 52 smaller shrines, creates a feeling of being surrounded by layers of devotion. Monks and worshippers move quietly, and the scent of incense lingers in the air, reinforcing a deeply meditative mood. Despite being a popular tourist attraction, the sanctity and serenity of the temple are remarkably preserved.

What truly sets Hutheesing Temple apart is the way it combines the spiritual and the aesthetic. The fine craftsmanship is not just art‚Äîit‚Äôs an expression of faith. Whether you‚Äôre religious or simply in search of a tranquil experience, the temple offers a moment of stillness and connection that lingers long after your visit.

In a world full of distractions, the Hutheesing Jain Temple provides a rare and beautiful pause. It is not just a place of worship, but a space where one can reconnect‚Äîwith self, silence, and the divine.

One of the wonderful temples with jain architecture. It was mesmerizing to see the detailed carvings in the limestones. The surrounding walkways arches were built beautifully. Also the place was well maintained. Overall it's a peaceful place of worship.

Bai Harir Vav, also known as the Bai Harir Stepwell, is a stunning example of Indo-Islamic architecture located in Ahmedabad. Built in the 15th century, it served as a crucial water reservoir during a time of drought and showcases remarkable engineering.

Highlights for Visitors:

Architecture: The stepwell features intricate carvings, pillars, and arches, highlighting the craftsmanship of the period. The detailed stonework and geometric patterns are particularly impressive.

Historical Significance: It reflects the engineering ingenuity of the time and is a testament to the importance of water conservation in arid regions.

Photography: The unique structure, especially when illuminated by sunlight filtering through the arches, provides excellent photography opportunities. Photography not permitted inside the mosque.

Atmosphere: Bai Harir Vav offers an environment, ideal for exploration on non crowded days.

Tips for Visiting:

Best Time to Visit: Early morning or late afternoon is ideal for pleasant weather and better lighting for photos.

Access: Be prepared for many stairs, unsafe ledges and uneven surfaces, as it's a stepwell with multiple levels. Many restrictions in the mosque area.

Respect the Space: As a historical site, visitors should maintain decorum and respect the site's integrity.

reviews.reviewText:
During 1956, Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Institute of Indology was established with the joint efforts of Shri. Kasturbhai Lalbhai, a wellknown and prominent Ahmedabad based industrialist, and Jain Acharya Muni. Punyavijayji. Muni. Punyavijayji donated his personal collection of illustrated and un-illustrated manuscripts, bronzes and cloth paintings at time at the establishment of Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Indological Institute. With the passage of time the collection grew more and more prominent which created a need for an exclusive display of the artifacts. Thus, in 1984 a new building adjacent to the L.D. Institute of Indology was built by internationally acclaimed architect Shri. Balakrishna Doshi. The L.D. Museum was formally inaugurated by Shri. Brajkumar Nehru, the then Governor of Gujarat in 1985.

Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum is open from 10:30 AM in the morning till 5:30 PM in the evening on all days except for Mondays and public holidays. For group visits, the museum has to be informed earlier and can take a guided tour. There is no entry fee to visit Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum.
This houses a significant collection of Jain art, including sculptures, scrolls, manuscripts, and miniature paintings.¬†Its architecture, designed by renowned architect Balkrishna Doshi, is notable for its integration of modernist and brutalist elements, with a focus on natural light and ventilation.
The Lalbhai Dalpatbhai (LD) Museum in Ahmedabad, India, is a case study in museum design and its connection to the preservation and display of cultural heritage
Overall a very enriching experience.  Must visit.

They allow photography on lower floor which is the department of sculptures. Photography is prohibited on upper floor which is paintings section. The collection is not large but well maintained. Entry is free. They give free pamphlets highlighting the museum collection.

Nestled in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, the **Lalbhai Dalpatbhai Museum** is a treasure trove of Indian art, history, and culture. Established in 1984, the museum is housed within the serene campus of the LD Institute of Indology. Its collection boasts over 76,000 rare manuscripts, intricate miniature paintings, sculptures, wood carvings, and coins, dating back to ancient and medieval India. A highlight is its stunning Jain artifacts and bronze sculptures that showcase exceptional craftsmanship. The museum's tranquil setting and well-curated displays offer a perfect blend of learning and reflection. Ideal for history buffs and art enthusiasts, it promises an enriching experience into India‚Äôs artistic heritage.

The Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel National Memorial in Ahmedabad is a truly enriching experience for anyone interested in Indian history and the life of the "Iron Man of India." Housed in the beautiful Moti Shahi Mahal palace, the memorial expertly blends historical significance with modern interactive exhibits. The museum is well-maintained and provides a comprehensive look into Sardar Patel's life and his pivotal role in unifying India. The surrounding gardens offer a peaceful and calming atmosphere, making it a great place for a reflective visit. The 3D laser show is a definite highlight, providing a powerful and engaging narrative of the independence movement.
However, a notable issue that detracts from the experience is the problem of rainwater leakage. During my visit, it was apparent that the auditorium and some areas of the museum were not immune to water seepage during heavy rains, which is a concern for the preservation of the building and its contents. While the memorial is a must-visit, this particular maintenance issue should be addressed to ensure the long-term integrity of this important historical site. Despite this, the memorial is an excellent tribute and well worth the visit for its educational and historical value.

The Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel National Memorial, commonly known as the Sardar Patel Museum, is located in Ahmedabad, Gujarat, India. It is a significant cultural and historical museum dedicated to the life and legacy of Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel, the first Deputy Prime Minister and Home Minister of independent India, known for his role in integrating India and his leadership during the freedom struggle.

Here is a detailed review of the museum:

Location and History

The museum is housed in a heritage building called the Moti Shahi Mahal, which was originally built in the 16th century by Shah Jahan. The palace was later renovated and repurposed as a memorial to Sardar Patel. The museum opened in 1978 and has since served as an important center for historical education about Sardar Patel and the Indian independence movement.

Exhibits and Collections

The museum has a vast collection of items related to Sardar Patel‚Äôs life, as well as the broader context of India‚Äôs independence movement. Some of the key features include:

1. Sardar Patel‚Äôs Life and Contributions:

The museum showcases personal items of Sardar Patel, including his letters, photographs, and documents.

It covers his early life, political career, and his critical role in the integration of princely states into the Indian Union after independence.

Displays include a detailed account of his contributions to the freedom struggle and his leadership in post-independence India.

2. Galleries and Exhibits:

The museum has several galleries dedicated to different aspects of India‚Äôs history, such as the Indian National Movement, and the Integration of Princely States.

The most prominent exhibit is the ‚ÄúIron Man of India‚Äù section, which is dedicated to Patel's personality and leadership qualities.

Artifacts from Patel‚Äôs political career, such as his correspondence with other leaders of the time (including Mahatma Gandhi), and historical documents are carefully preserved here.

3. Interactive Displays and Audio-Visuals:

The museum has well-curated displays of photographs, sculptures, and paintings.

The museum employs audio-visuals to engage visitors and explain the historical events surrounding the life of Patel and his era.

4. Sardar Patel's Role in the Integration of India:

There is an emphasis on Patel‚Äôs strategic role in convincing princely states to join the Indian Union post-independence. This exhibit is particularly insightful, explaining how Patel‚Äôs diplomacy and leadership ensured the political unity of India.

5. The Role of the Police in Indian Freedom Struggle:

The museum also has an interesting section dedicated to Gujarat Police's involvement in India‚Äôs freedom struggle, showcasing the contributions of the police forces in maintaining law and order during the turbulent times.

6. Personal Belongings:

The museum displays Patel‚Äôs personal belongings such as his clothes, accessories, and other memorabilia, which adds a personal touch to the exhibits.

7. Relics from the Mahatma's Movement:

The museum features important documents and artifacts from the Gandhi Movement, particularly focusing on Patel's close collaboration with Mahatma Gandhi during the freedom struggle.

Architectural Significance

The museum is housed in a beautiful building that is itself a historical landmark. The Moti Shahi Mahal has a blend of traditional Gujarati and Islamic architectural styles. The intricately carved wooden windows, ornate arches, and a grand entrance make it an architectural marvel.

The building‚Äôs design includes wide courtyards, spacious halls, and high ceilings, creating a grand yet inviting atmosphere. The traditional architectural elements complement the artifacts inside and enhance the overall visitor experience.

Visitor Experience

The museum is well-maintained and organized, offering a good flow for visitors to move through the exhibits without feeling crowded. The displays are well-labelled, and some sections are interactive, making it engaging for visitors of all ages.

reviews.reviewText:
I recently visited Rani no Hajiro in Ahmedabad, which is a great place for shopping. You can find beautiful traditional clothes, jewellery, and accessories at very good prices.
After shopping, I went to Manekchowk, which is very famous for street food. I tried Mahalaxmi Bhajipav, sandwich, and the popular gotala dosa. everything was delicious! The place is full of energy at night and perfect for food lovers.

‚ÄúRani no Hajiro: A Hidden Gem in Ahmedabad‚Äù

Rani no Hajiro is a beautiful yet underrated historical site tucked away in the bustling Manek Chowk food area. It‚Äôs a hidden gem surrounded by local residences and the lively old bazaar, offering a unique blend of history and everyday life.

What Makes It Special:
‚Ä¢	Intricate Architecture: The beautiful windows with intricate carvings and neglected yet charming structures give it a timeless aura. It‚Äôs a treat for architecture enthusiasts and photographers.
‚Ä¢	Hidden Location: The site is well-hidden and not overly crowded, adding to its charm as a peaceful escape amidst the chaos of Manek Chowk.

Things to Note:
‚Ä¢	Neglect and Maintenance: Unfortunately, the structures are not well-maintained, and the surrounding area can feel a bit neglected.
‚Ä¢	Accessibility: You can‚Äôt take your car here‚Äîit‚Äôs best to park on the main road and explore the area on foot. Walking through the narrow lanes of the old bazaar is an experience in itself.
‚Ä¢	Ask for Directions: Don‚Äôt rely solely on Google Maps. It‚Äôs better to ask locals for directions, as the area can be tricky to navigate.

Tips:
‚Ä¢	Combine your visit with a stroll through the old bazaar and enjoy the food and vibe of Manek Chowk.
‚Ä¢	Be prepared for some walking, and take your time exploring this hidden slice of Ahmedabad‚Äôs history.

If you‚Äôre a lover of history and hidden treasures, Rani no Hajiro is worth the visit despite its challenges. It‚Äôs a glimpse into the city‚Äôs rich past amidst its thriving present!

Rani no Hajiro: A Hidden Gem for Unique Accessories (with a Caveat)
Rani no Hajiro in Ahmedabad might not impress you at first glance. The historical monument itself appears somewhat shabby. However, look beyond the exterior and you'll discover a hidden gem for unique women's accessories.

Treasure Trove of Trinkets

The area surrounding the tomb is a haven for budget-friendly shopping. Here, you'll find a variety of shops selling everything from stunning handcrafted accessories (starting as low as ‚Çπ50!) to beautiful dupattas and chaniya cholis. The selection is truly impressive, and I personally found myself drawn to the unique pieces, ultimately leaving with a collection worth ‚Çπ2,000.

Essentials and Refreshment

While exploring the shops, you'll also find refreshment stalls offering a quick pick-me-up. Public restrooms are available for a small fee, but be warned ‚Äì their cleanliness might leave something to be desired.

Food Paradise Nearby

After your shopping spree, head to the nearby Manek Chowk, a foodie's paradise, for a delightful and well-deserved meal. Don't forget to put your bargaining skills to the test here as well!

Things to Keep in Mind

While Rano no Hajiro offers a unique shopping experience, there are a few things to consider:

Condition of the Monument: The historical structure itself is not well-maintained and may appear neglected.
Basic Amenities: Public restrooms are available but might not be the cleanest.
Recommendation:

Rani no Hajiro is perfect for those seeking one-of-a-kind accessories at affordable prices. However, if you're expecting a pristine historical site, you might be disappointed.

So, if you're an adventurous shopper who can overlook the monument's condition, head to Rani no Hajiro and unleash your inner bargain hunter! Just remember to factor in a post-shopping meal at the vibrant Manek Chowk!

Indroda Park is a wonderful blend of nature, wildlife, and education. Known as India‚Äôs Jurassic Park, it features life-size dinosaur models, a zoo, and beautiful botanical gardens. The greenery, well-maintained walking trails, and informative displays make it a perfect spot for families, students, and nature lovers. A visit here is both enjoyable and educational.

I recently had the opportunity to visit Indroda Park, and overall, it was a refreshing and memorable experience. The park offers an abundance of natural beauty, with greenery spread across vast areas, creating a calm and peaceful environment for visitors. The sight of peacocks freely moving around the park was truly delightful and added a unique charm to the surroundings. Additionally, the dinosaur sculptures were very impressive, well-designed, and engaging, especially for children, making the park both educational and entertaining.

While the visit was enjoyable, I would like to share a few observations for improvement. One of the major concerns is the absence of a proper map or clear guidance for visitors. Without directional boards and signages at key points, it becomes difficult to navigate the large park area, which can sometimes cause confusion and inconvenience. A simple visitor map and more visible signboards would greatly enhance the overall experience.

Another aspect that could be reconsidered is the food policy. While I fully appreciate and support the ban on plastic, the restriction on carrying fruits or baby food creates challenges for families with infants and young children. Allowing baby food or basic fruit items, with proper checking, would make the visit much more convenient for parents.

Lastly, the staff support could be more approachable and visitor-friendly. A little more guidance, courtesy, and assistance from the staff would add immense value to the visitor experience.

Indroda Park is undoubtedly a gem of natural and educational attractions, but with a few improvements in facilities and services, it can become even more visitor-friendly and enjoyable. I sincerely hope the management considers these suggestions for enhancing the comfort and satisfaction of future visitors.

Indroda Nature Park, also known as the "Jurassic Park of India," is a unique biological park located in Gandhinagar, near Ahmedabad, Gujarat. Spread over 400 hectares along the banks of the Sabarmati River, it is managed by the Gujarat Ecological Education and Research (GEER) Foundation. The park is ideal for nature lovers, families, students, and wildlife enthusiasts.

One of the park‚Äôs main attractions is its Dinosaur and Fossil Section, which features life-size dinosaur models and fossil remains, making it a hit among children and curious minds. The park also houses a zoo, an aviary, a botanical garden, a reptile section, and a marine aquarium. There are dedicated areas for deer, peacocks, crocodiles, and other animals, all set in a natural environment.

It‚Äôs a perfect place for a day picnic with ample walking trails, shaded spots, and educational signboards throughout. The park is open from 8:00 AM to 6:00 PM, closed on Mondays. Entry tickets are reasonably priced, with special rates for children and students.

Carry water, wear comfortable shoes, and be prepared for a lot of walking. Indroda Park offers a peaceful, educational, and refreshing escape from city life.

Indroda Nature Park in Gandhinagar is a peaceful and educational place, often called India‚Äôs Jurassic Park. It has life-size dinosaur models, fossil displays, and even a dinosaur egg hatchery. The park also has a small zoo with animals such as lion tiger and leopard, plus green gardens and open spaces to walk or relax.

It‚Äôs affordable, clean, and a good spot for families, students, and nature lovers. its best when visited in monsoon.  Carrying your own snacks is helpful as food options are limited. Overall, it‚Äôs a great place to enjoy nature and learn something new at the same time.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Amdavad Ni Gufa is a renowned art gallery in the city, known for its contemporary and cavernous design. The space was designed by the celebrated architect Balkrishna V Doshi and features artwork by legendary Indian artist Maqbool Fida Husain. The gallery's unique cave-like structure makes it stand out among modern architecture in India, with interconnected domes supported by tree-like pillars.
placeMetadata.address: 2GPX+GW6, Kasturbhai Lalbhai Campus Opp Gujarat University campus, CEPT campus, Navrangpura, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380009, India

reviews.reviewText: A unique underground art gallery with a very creative and peaceful vibe. The architecture is unlike anything else dome-shaped, cave-like, and beautifully lit. Showcases modern art in a truly unusual setting. Worth a visit if you‚Äôre into art, design, or just something different in the city.

The cave is unique! Once you go in you‚Äôll understand what the murals and the structures are trying to convey. Well made! There‚Äôs a nice cafe where like-minded people sit and discuss art. A gallery is there as well with fee entry

The Amdavad ni Gufa was built during my final years at CEPT, a time when it captured the imagination of every student. Its cave-like form was mesmerizing, not just for its concept but also for its unconventional construction techniques, particularly the use of ferrocement.

Colleagues who had worked at B.V. Doshi‚Äôs office shared fascinating insights‚ÄîDoshi, the visionary Pritzker Prize-winning architect, would often sketch directly on-site, and the team would build from those sketches. The steps leading to the Gufa‚Äôs entrance, they say, were first marked directly on the ground, constructed, and only then documented into drawings.

The shimmering china mosaic domes were a source of fascination for students. It was commonly referred to as the "Doshi-Hussain Gufa," though originally named "Hussain-Doshi Gufa" before it was dedicated to the people of Ahmedabad and rechristened "Amdavad ni Gufa."

At the back, a door and pathway evoke images of Indus Valley Civilization structures unearthed at Lothal and Mohenjodaro, with a ramp descending into the earth. The intricate designs on the door grills add to its enigmatic charm.

A building with no defined purpose‚Äîsimply a place to sit, read, and reflect. M.F. Hussain had painted spontaneous, sketch-like figures on the interior domes, though nothing substantial. Some of his cutout drawings remain, adding to the ambiance. Children are particularly enthralled by the mysterious structure. For years, they were allowed to play atop the domes, but recently, this has been restricted to preserve the aging china mosaic.

A marvel of architecture, the Gufa stands strong‚Äîthough perhaps in the near future, it may require thoughtful restoration to preserve its legacy.

I visited Amdavad ni Gufa out of curiosity, and while it was interesting, it didn't totally blow me away.

The architecture is unique - like an underground art cave - and it's cool to see something so different in the middle of the city. The combination of B.V. Doshi's design and M.F. Husain's artwork gives it a lot of cultural value, and it's great for people who are into modern art or unusual spaces.

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Kamla Nehru Zoological Garden, also known as Kankaria Zoo, is a wildlife park located in Ahmedabad. placeMetadata.name: Patang Kite Museum

sources.snippet: 3 km from city center 42 out of 64 Places To Visit in Ahmedabad. Housed in the premises of Sanskar Kendra in Paldi, Ahmedabad, Kite Museum was conceptualised and created by Bhanubhai Shah. Designed by the renowned architect Le Corbusier in 1954, the museum is an elaborate display of about 125 uniquely carved kites including mirror embroidered kites, block print kites and Japanese kites such as Rokuku.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Ahmedabad | Top Tourist Attractions

placeMetadata.description: Exhibits of rare, patterned kites in a modernist building designed by French architect Le Corbusier.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: The Patang Kite Museum in Ahmedabad is a modernist building designed by the renowned French architect Le Corbusier. It houses a collection of rare and patterned kites, making it India's first kite museum and the second in the world. The museum was established when Shri Bhanubhai Shah donated his extensive collection of kites to the Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation.
placeMetadata.address: 2H79+6M9, Sankar Kender, Bhagtacharya Rd, Kocharab, Paldi, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380007, India

reviews.reviewText: Located on Bhagtacharya road, Kocharab, Paldi at Ahmedabad, the kite museum is a nice place, especially for kids to see first hand the beautiful art of kites. Gujarat is synonymous with kite flying during the Uttarayan festival. During this time of the year, the sky is rendered colorful with kites flying all over the sky in unimaginable sizes, shapes, & color. Irrespective of caste, creed, or religion, Gujaratis fly kites during this festival. The museum is located within Sanskar Kendra, designed by Le Corbusier. It is mentioned that the thought of setting up such a museum came to Sri. Bhanubhai Shah when he gave away his collection of kites to Ahmedabad Municipal Corporation, which also incidentally manages the place. The museum also has display of several historical aspects of kite flying since the ancient times. It's astonishing to read about the different types of kites from other parts of the world & how this art has evolved over the ages. The museum is easily accessible by different modes of transport. Overall, a beautiful place to visit with kids. üëåüëåüáÆüá≥üáÆüá≥

3 stars because it was closed and I have no clue What's inside. However I was able to spot some beautiful old rock art. Again these beautiful sculptures were very amazing to look at but there was no history or details written anywhere around. All we can do is imagine what could it have been in the past.
Maybe if they do some more work on it, I will prefer going there again.

Designed by Le Corbusier to exhibit the history of kites and its making. Its combination of brick and concrete creates a softened look which contrasts with the Brutalist Tagore Hall opposite the museum. Currently, the museum is closed due to a major need for restoration, as it is quite dilapidated, due to the concrete planters breaking off or having been pulled for safety reasons. It was poorly made at an early stage, so it wasn‚Äôt able to last long.

placeMetadata.name: Conflictorium

sources.snippet: India's first participatory museum is a look at Gujarat‚Äôs long history of conflict, and the way ahead. Launched by Avni Sethi in 2013, the Conflictorium includes a conflict timeline, which chronicles the violent and oppressive past of Gujarat be it in the Gallery of Disputes, which highlights the root causes of rows, or the Moral Compass, which makes the Constitution accessible.Timings: 11 am-8 pm(Mon closed); Tickets: free
sources.shortName: 22 places to visit in Ahmedabad that are not tourist traps

placeMetadata.description: Interactive museum with exhibits designed to facilitate dialogue about historical conflicts via art.
placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Nestled in the vibrant Mirzapur area of Ahmedabad, Conflictorium: Museum of Conflict is a unique interactive museum that invites visitors to engage with the complexities of historical conflicts through art. This thought-provoking space aims to foster dialogue and understanding around contentious issues while serving as a resource center for peace and support for marginalized communities.
placeMetadata.address: Conflictorium, Gool Lodge Mirzapur Road opp. RC High School Of Commerce, nr. Chalte Peer Ni Dargah, Delhi Chakla, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380001, India

reviews.reviewText: Best museum in the city. Stays true to its name and the intention of curating every event by the organisers and artists here is so pointed and a beautiful reflection of society. Must must visit.

A very thought-provoking place to visit if you feel passionately about India, its people and its long but successful struggle for independence. Conflictorium will make you question whether that hard-earned freedom truly exists today in this post-truth world or not.

It‚Äôs not about seeing something amazing. Even if you feel happy, it might make your heart ache a little to witness the silence and sadness. At least, that‚Äôs what I experienced. It‚Äôs best to visit when you‚Äôre feeling overwhelmed and want to reflect in silence.

"The Conflictorium in Ahmedabad is a groundbreaking participatory museum that delves into the complexities of conflict within society. Housed in the historic Gool Lodge, once owned by Bachuben Nagarwala‚Äîthe city's first trained beautician and hairstylist‚Äîthis space offers a profound journey through various facets of discord and reconciliation.

The museum features several thought-provoking installations:

Conflict Timeline: Chronicles Gujarat's history of conflicts since 1960, providing deep insights into the state's past.

Gallery of Disputes: Utilizes animal allegories to depict societal conflicts, drawing inspiration from works like the 'Panchatantra' and George Orwell's 'Animal Farm.'

Empathy Alley: Showcases silhouettes of influential leaders such as Mahatma Gandhi and Dr. B.R. Ambedkar, accompanied by recordings of their impactful speeches.

Moral Compass: Allows visitors to engage directly with a pre-1977 copy of the Indian Constitution, emphasizing the importance of understanding our rights and duties.

Memory Lab: Encourages guests to share personal stories of conflict, fostering a sense of community and understanding.

Sorry Tree: A poignant installation where visitors can leave notes of apology, promoting healing and forgiveness.

Located opposite R.C. High School of Commerce near Chalte Peer Ni Dargah in Mirzapur, visitors can conveniently park their vehicles at the nearby parking area and cross the road to reach the museum.

The Conflictorium is open from Tuesday to Sunday, 11:00 AM to 8:00 PM, and offers free entry. It's a must-visit for anyone interested in exploring societal issues through art and interactive exhibits.

This museum not only educates but also inspires introspection, making it a unique and invaluable experience in Ahmedabad."
Damn! The audio quality was sometimes not comprehensive but the overall content is pretty solid and can lead to anything from self reflection to hefty debates.

I walked in with high expectations, and while the space didn‚Äôt fully match them, it still had its moments.
One section that really touched me was the jar of handwritten notes ‚Äî strangers pouring their hearts out in ink. That felt raw, human, and real.
The rest of the experience was moderate for me, but if you're someone who enjoys exploring thoughts, spaces, and silence ‚Äî it's definitely worth a one-time visit.

A thoughtfully designed space, with well curated exhibits talking about the things which are not generally talked of. A really good initiative, somehow feels one sided in some aspects but nevertheless is a powerful representation of the topics it covers. Would totally recommend a visit here. Also it was a bit difficult to locate, as there's no indication of the space other than a small sign visible from only one side.

I recently met Mr. Jay Rathod and was impressed by his humility and wealth of information. He took the time to explain everything to me in great detail, ensuring I fully understood every aspect.During my visit, I also attended an event titled "Lost and Found in Space," an interactive and performative session led by Abhishek Kukreja. This session delved into how we access spaces and how these spaces shape our beliefs, memories, desires, identities, and even our transgressions.Abhishek Kukreja has extensive experience teaching and conducting workshops in film, theatre, cultural studies, and creative arts. As an educator at the Conflictorium, he is dedicated to promoting critical thinking and art appreciation through engaging dialogues and workshops.I highly recommend that everyone visit this place to experience the thought-provoking events and workshops they offer.

placeMetadata.name: Rajwadu

sources.snippet: Once you step into the portals of this experience, you would have stepped into a New World; a world, which takes you back in time.At ‚ÄúRajwadu‚Äù, we not only bring alive the traditional Indian and Gujarati culture but also harp on the need to preserve the same for future generations; quite simply because we want the myriad expressions which have come to occupy the faces to last and be passed on.The traditional welcome ‚Äì full of warmth; the leisurely saunter in lush green surrounds along lantern lit pathways and responsible for those manifold expressions; the courtyard temple with four generation idols; the works of art and the resplendent architecture of yesteryears; and much more, is what ‚ÄúRajwadu‚Äù is all about. Not to forget the cuisine and we ‚Äì your host; comprising of our in house ‚Äì staff whom we call members of our extended family and who breathe, day in and night out traditional hospitality. What we call ‚ÄúMehmangati‚Äù‚ÄúRajwadu‚Äù, a theme based restaurant spread over 12,000 sq.

That said, the ambiance is beautiful, offering a true feel of a Gujarati-Rajasthani village, with rustic decor and peaceful surroundings. It‚Äôs a great place to sit, relax, and soak in the traditional vibes after dinner. Worth a visit for the atmosphere, but hoping for more variety next time.

We recently visited Hotel Rajwadu in Ahmedabad and had the pleasure of enjoying their traditional Gujarati thali. The food was absolutely delicious, with every item on the plate prepared authentically and served with warmth. The ambience of the place is another highlight ‚Äì rustic, serene, and truly reflective of Gujarat‚Äôs cultural heritage.

One suggestion from our experience: the thali includes a wide variety of dishes, often more than one can consume in a single meal. While this generosity is appreciated, it can sometimes lead to food wastage, especially when diners are unable to finish everything. A thoughtful approach could be to serve a basic minimum set of dishes initially, and then offer additional items based on individual preference or request. This could help reduce food wastage without compromising the guest experience.

Overall, it was a memorable dining experience ‚Äì excellent food, great service, and a wonderful setting. Highly recommended for anyone who wants to relish authentic Gujarati cuisine in a traditional ambience.

reviews.reviewText:
We recently visited The Project Cafe, also known as yellow house, which offers both outdoor and indoor seating option.

--> Outdoor Seating:- The outdoor  area is surrounded by small plants and covered with vines, allowing sunlight to filter through, creating a charming and aesthetic atmosphere.

--> Indoor Seating:- For those sensitive to heat, there's AC indoor seating and non-AC options on first floor. The indoor environment is pleasant, enhanced by unique sealing lamps.

--> Taste:- I would rate the food a 7.8/10. We ordered four items: classic Margherita, signature Cold coffee, watermelon juice, and chocolate pancakes with maple syrup (contains egg).

‚Ä¢ Classic Margherita: The thin crust was topped with large slices of tomato but lacked sufficient Szechuan sauce.

‚Ä¢ Signature Cold Coffee:- This was quite unremarkable.

‚Ä¢ Watermelon Juice:- Completely fresh and natural, I would rate it 5/5.

‚Ä¢ Chocolate Pancakes: Served with guava and apple pieces. Along with maple syrup and vanilla ice cream, these were enjoyable.

--> Staff and Customer Service:- We really appreciated the demeanor of the manager and staff there. They spoke to us with a lot of humility and addressed our problems with a smile, providing solutions. The waiter who served our food appeared to be quite experienced and had excellent skills in interacting with customers. When my friend accidentally spilled juice, the waiter cleaned it up without showing any annoyance, simply saying, "No worries, it happens." After cleaning, he even asked my friend if she was okay?, which truly brightened our day.

While we found the prices a bit high for the taste, outstanding customer service definitely makes us want to visit again.

I visited The Project Cafe today, and while the ambience was quite nice, the overall experience didn‚Äôt quite match up to the price point. I ordered the spaghetti, and honestly, it didn‚Äôt feel worth the cost. The taste was average‚Äînothing special or memorable that would justify the premium pricing. Given the high expectations that come with such a place, the food could have been much better in terms of flavor and portion size.

That being said, the vibe of the cafe was good, with a cozy and artistic atmosphere. But if you‚Äôre looking for a place where the food truly matches the price, this might not be the best choice.

Visually, the place nails it‚Äîaesthetic corners and perfect for photos. The vibe is definitely a win. That said, the food didn‚Äôt quite live up to the price. It wasn‚Äôt bad, just felt a bit average for the premium. Great for the ambience, but I wouldn‚Äôt go back just for the menu.

These guys changed the menu; earlier, North Indian food was served. I am disappointed that fewer options are available, despite good food quality and service. I hope they start serving their signature dishes again.

Had seen a lot of Instagram reels about this place and decided to visit with a group of four. We all ordered different things ‚Äì from hot chocolate to shakes to affogato. Overall, the taste was pretty average. As a hardcore affogato lover, I found theirs quite disappointing. My friend wanted to try a brownie shake but was told all their brownies contain egg, so he went with another shake, which turned out to be overly sweet ‚Äì we had to ask them to replace it. A decent one-time visit, but nothing that would pull us back.

It's really a very cozy place to seat and chill. Yeah it's a bit overpriced but the taste is really really good and also loved the service. It's just that in outdoor area seatings, smoking is allowed so it makes uncomfortable for the other table. Otherwise food, service, atmosphere, ambience is really 5/5.

Based on our previous experiences (although we visited years back) this was on the list of good & worth visiting cafes! But this time we had very bad experience in terms of food & cleanliness.

reviews.reviewText: Delicious food with great flavors and perfect presentation! Every bite was enjoyable, and the quality was top-notch. It was a truly satisfying experience. Coffee was average in taste, but other food is very tasty and perfect in taste. Definitely love to visit again. Little high in price but worth visiting.

Ordered veggie overload and bbq chicken pizzas. I had the bbq chicken and it was average. What was the need to add brown onions ü§î and the chicken was not tasting good. We shared the pizza between 2 people and left one slice because we couldn't eat it. The veg version was decent.
As this was my first visit, I'll give it another try and see if I can change my overview on this place.

The Blue Oven at Bodakdev delivers an experience that blends authenticity with a relaxed, cozy vibe. I visited recently, and the overall experience was delightful.

The place serves authentic Italian-style pizza, and you can truly feel the difference ‚Äî right from the dough to the perfectly balanced toppings. The 'make your own pizza' option is a fun and interactive touch that makes the meal even more special.

‚ú® Taste: Every bite feels fresh and flavorful. Their use of real Italian herbs, wood-fired base, and minimal oil makes the food both tasty and light.

üë®‚Äçüç≥ Service: Staff is polite, quick, and well-informed. They guide you well while customizing pizzas or picking from the menu.

üí∞ Price: Reasonable for the quality and ambiance ‚Äî around ‚Çπ600 for two. Not super cheap, but worth every rupee.

üçù Variety: From classic Margherita to Smoky Chicken or Pepperoni, their menu covers wide Italian bases ‚Äî pastas, garlic breads, salads, and even refreshing beverages like Mint Mojito.

‚úîÔ∏è Authenticity: This isn't your regular Indo-Italian fusion pizza. The crust, the cheese, and the sauces truly stand out as authentic Italian.

A must-visit for pizza lovers who want something beyond the usual franchise taste!"

You can easily call this place "The blue Heaven" instead of Oven. I know it sounds cheesy but hey, that's what they serve.

I honestly had the best Mozzarella and Parmesan at this place.

Service was phenomenal, they have this ring system where you just have to press a button and they will assist you, and it was necessary as this place has floors.

Let's talk food - The Skinny Margherita has amazing balance of Marinara sauce, Mozzarella and basil leaves. Tear & Share garlic bread was a little bland but you can season it yourself a bit. 4 cheese pizza was just okay-ish. What won my heart was Penne Primavera and Avocado on Toast. Rich smooth texture of Avocado with crispy toast was wonderful and cherry tomato was literally cherry on top.

But Ambience is the reason why I'll visit again. You can enjoy your food and have a private conversation with your date or family. Soft lightning feels very cozy and makes you want to stay longer, although during peak hours it does get crowded a bit, for best first experience, visit by 7PM-8PM.

Overall, I loved this place and I shall continue to try other items on menu as they seems to amaze me every time.

Ratings: 4.2/5.¬†Loved¬†it.

The Blue Oven in Bodakdev is nothing short of a pizza lover's paradise! Every visit feels like a celebration of flavors, shared with family and friends. The artisanal pizzas, crafted with high-quality ingredients and baked to perfection in their signature Napoli-style "Blue" oven, are a testament to their dedication to excellence.

The ambiance is warm and inviting, making it the perfect spot for cherished moments with loved ones. Whether it's their classic garlic bread, the indulgent Nutella pizza, or the perfectly balanced Deluxe Veggie Pizza, every bite is a delightful journey. The relaxed atmosphere and friendly staff add to the charm, ensuring a memorable dining experience every time.

For anyone seeking a place where great food meets great memories, The Blue Oven is a must-visit. It's not just a restaurant; it's a tradition of joy and togetherness.

reviews.reviewText:
Absolutely loved the place. The ambience is welcoming, the interiors are done well. The food is excellent. My picks were Baked beans on toast and crinkle cut fries. The fries are different from the regular ones, as they are made with skin of the potato left, which adds to the crunch. Baked beans on toast is just excellent with a thick toasted bread and a generous amount of cream cheese.

Coffee is good (though I'd have liked more options). The lotus biscoff cheesecake is something to die for. Too good.

Overall, its an excellent breakfast spot.

Loved the delicious food and this place has a really good vibe. I would say that service could be better. We almost spent 3 hours there. Place was quite and not noisy like other cafes. I didn't like the quantity of the food as a dish costing you 400/- to 500/- is not enough to fulfill 2 person's hunger. So if you're choosing this place, be ready to spend at least 1000 to 1200/- per person.

I would say this is a good place to hangout with friends. The place looks small but it's big from the inside and there are board games and cards as well to keep you busy.

I felt the service was slow. Even though there wasn't much rush when I went but they took quite some time for our order to be prepared especially the hot coffee we ordered. It came after we eat most of our food.

Apart from that, I also felt the restaurant to be reasonable priced and food quality and taste was above average, a good one time experience.

Although, I went for dinner and my review is solely based on that. I would however love to try their brunch menu, it seemed pretty good.

Soul square is more than just a cafe, it's a warm embrace on a chilly day. From the moment you step inside, you're enveloped in a comforting atmosphere. The soft lighting, plush seating, and gentle music create the perfect ambiance for relaxation.

So I went there with my friend on his birthday! Been to this cafe a lot of time last year but this time the vibes were great, but the service and the time it took to get our food on the table was too long, the owners were nice and gave us a complimentary dish for late order!

The food taste, quality and quantity was dicey, the noodles were all mushy and not so great but the Korean chicken was good but the quantity was less! Overall I‚Äôd say it is a costly place! Worth a visit once.

reviews.reviewText: The handicrafts are so unique and beautifully crafted. The price is reasonable and totally worth the beauty. The sculptures are so minutely detailed. Peaceful, Mesmerizing and Relaxing place. The reason behind deducting 2 stars was the dirtiness. There were bits of paper and wrappers, Tins and cans and the public didn't even spare the lake. The lake is very polluted. It hurts to see that this garden which is situated in such a posh area has such poor management! There should be fine in producing waste and making the place dirty, there should be awareness on cleanliness. Every Sunday when there are maximum visitors, cleanliness drives should be held so that visitors and especially children understand the importance of cleanliness. There should be CCTV cameras so, that no one throws waste in the park. Increase Dustbins in the park.

sources.snippet: 2 km from city center 46 out of 64 Places To Visit in Ahmedabad. Victoria Garden is situated in the south of Ahmedabad near Bhadra Fort. The garden spells beauty and charm with its well-maintained lawns, pretty flower beds, rejuvenation trees and spacious play areas.

This well-maintained garden features lush lawns for various activities and picnics, along with seating areas and a beautiful fountain. Visitors can admire the statue of Queen Victoria while enjoying the serene surroundings filled with carefully tended shrubs and grass.

reviews.reviewText: This garden is a perfect spot for nature lovers. It is clean, green, and well-maintained, offering a refreshing escape from the city's hustle. The large area provides plenty of space for walking, jogging, and relaxing. Mornings here are peaceful, making it an ideal time for meditation or exercise. However, the garden gets quite crowded in the evening. The nearby BRTS stop adds to the convenience of reaching the place easily. Overall, a great spot for relaxation and fresh air!
Excellent place. Huge Parking available. Had lunch in the quiet, lush green garden. Very clean and well maintained. No one interrupted during the lunch. Could absorb nature .........thanks

On the other hand, when I talked about cleanliness, it's not up to the mark, neither instruments nor washroom and garden.

Maintenance of this park impressed me too much. Literally i appreciate it. Back of the park one may go to riverfront and atal foot over bridge.

it‚Äôs a piece of heaven in town ! restored as part of the u n mehta foundation initiative to improve parks in the city - this over 100 year park is a bit of magic !

I visited this place to see the statue of Lokmanya Tilak erected by Mahatma Gandhi here in 1929. There was long struggle to get this done. The garden in its renovated version is quite beautiful. Originally it had Queen Victoria's statue too, which can be seen in Museum at Paldi.

placeMetadata.name: Science City Ahmedabad

sources.snippet: 9 km from city center 15 out of 64 Places To Visit in Ahmedabad. Located on the Science City Road in Ahmedabad, Gujarat Science City is a remarkable initiative taken up by the Government of Gujarat to spread general awareness and a scientific temperament especially among the youth of the country. Spread over 107 hectares of land, the centre also holds frequent talk shows and workshops for students and science enthusiasts.
sources.shortName: 52 Best Places to visit in Ahmedabad | Top Tourist Attractions

placeMetadata.generatedDescription: Science City Ahmedabad is a must-visit destination for science enthusiasts. This museum offers an engaging experience that promotes scientific curiosity and learning. With 13 main sections featuring state-of-the-art facilities, visitors can explore various aspects of science in an entertaining and educational manner. The newly added Aquarium and Robo Museum are particularly impressive, showcasing captivating installations and displays that captivate the imagination.
placeMetadata.address: Thaltej, Ahmedabad, Gujarat 380060, India

reviews.reviewText:
I recently had the opportunity to visit Science City with my mother‚Äôs school, Jotana Mishra School, where she is the principal. She invited me to join a group of 50 students to explore the place and gain knowledge.

The visit was an enriching experience, offering a perfect blend of education and entertainment. The interactive exhibits, live demonstrations, and advanced science models made complex concepts easy to understand. The Space and Astronomy section was particularly fascinating, showcasing detailed information about the universe. The Aquatic Gallery and Robotics Exhibition were also highlights, providing an engaging and hands-on experience.

The infrastructure of Science City is well-maintained, with spacious galleries and well-organized displays. The staff was helpful in explaining various exhibits, making the learning process even more enjoyable. The students had an exciting time, actively participating in different activities.

Overall, Science City is a must-visit for anyone interested in science and innovation. It serves as a great educational destination for students and adults alike, offering a fun way to learn about scientific advancements. I truly enjoyed the experience and would highly recommend it!

Visited aquarium, robotic, robot cafe. All places well maintained. Food is delicious in cafe. Nature park is also good. Water ride are not in working condition. Thrill ride is ok. Many food court at different spots.

Loved my visit to Science City! I booked my ticket through the app‚Äîit was super easy and showed options for combo passes and single entries. I chose Combo 1, which cost around ‚Çπ345 per person and covered many key attractions (the app even has a built-in map that shows where to go next).

I‚Äôd suggest reaching around 12‚Äì1 pm, especially since it‚Äôs a huge complex and there‚Äôs quite a bit of walking. If you‚Äôre not up for too much walking, they offer golf carts for a small fee‚Äîdefinitely useful.

Highlights for me:
‚Ä¢	Thrill ride‚Äîa fun, must-try experience.
‚Ä¢	Aquarium‚Äîabsolutely amazing, especially the shark tunnel and penguins.
‚Ä¢	Robotics gallery‚Äîgreat learning experience, interesting to see all the robot displays.
‚Ä¢	Plant section (Life Science Park)‚Äîso many species, really peaceful.
‚Ä¢	Nature Park‚Äîincredible, but huge‚ÄîI couldn‚Äôt cover everything in one go.

Perfect place for kids to learn and explore‚Äîblend of fun, science, and nature. Highly recommend visiting!‚Äù

‚∏ª

Why This Works
‚Ä¢	Personal & clear: It sounds conversational and easy to read.
‚Ä¢	Actionable tips: Mentions buying via app with combos, timing advice, and golf carts.
‚Ä¢	Highlights variety: Covers rides, aquarium, robotics, plant section, and nature park.
‚Ä¢	Inviting tone: Emphasizes it‚Äôs great for kids and families.

Visit to experience the feel this place gives and learn science in a fun way.

This charming venue offers an array of dishes, from beautifully crafted dumplings and sandwiches to flavorful noodle plates.
